values: So last night I went to St. Petersburg, and while there took a walk down to the Pier. And there was something about last night... something about standing that and looking at the moon, and it's wonderful and awe inspiring reflection on the water that just calmed me. And I stood there against the freezing cold railing with the wind absolutely assaulting my face and hair and I thought about what on earth I'm going to do for the rest of my life... or even in the next year of it. And I smiled and closed my eyes as I realized, in comparison, how little that even mattered in contrast to the simple, uncomplicated beauty of the water painted with the moon. And as strands of my now hopelessly knotted hair whipped around my face, I was completely and totally at peace as I realized how capable a God who made all of that must be. A God who made waters so breathtaking and vast that when viewed appear endless; a God who made a sky and an atmosphere and stars and the moon for sometimes, it seems, nothing more than for me to simply enjoy; a God who, underneath the surface of this rippling tide created an entire 'nother world full of mystery that we've yet to fully understand and discover, for perhaps no other reason than for HIM to enjoy. And, in all of this, a God who is this powerful and this in control, to love ME and have a plan for ME and know ME... and suddenly worrying seemed, well, ridiculous. And the beauty of creation enveloped me as God whispered "Now do you see? Just... trust... ME." And if God can do that, God can certainly handle me, the creatED.

This whole idea of being a bondservant is really taking on significant meaning for me. I mean, what is a bondservant? How does it apply to my life? First of all, it would seem that a bondservant has some sort of debt to pay, an obligation of sorts. The thing about this is that we're not necesarily INDEBTED to Christ, at least as I understand it. Rather, it's a privelege to be a bondservant of Christ because of what He did for us; something we can give back. So while Christ paid our debts, the price He requests is our lives. So then perhaps that's the debt we owe, is ourselves and our worship. Another thing is that a bondservant accepts, with ho qualms, the authority of his master. I struggle here. Christ has absolute rule, absolute authority, and I need to remember tha next time I decide to just snatch my life out of God's hands and back into my own control; that as a bondservant of Christ, with Christ as my MASTER, Christ has authority and rule in my life; and THANK GOD for that! Lastly, a bondservant is loyal and dedicated to his or her master. So all of these things combined.... it would seem, in our culture, that to be a bondservant is not something to which we ASPIRE. This word is linked with slavery, with oppression, with servanthood and the abuse of authority. So perhaps then we need to change our thinking entirely. To be a bondservant to Christ does not link us with oppression, but with liberty, freedom, and true, raw LIFE. So perhaps it begins there, with a new mindset, a new outlook. And suddenly... I'm excited to be able to call myself a bondservant of Christ. To remember my position as UNDER THE AUTHORITY of Christ, and instead of be frightened of taht loss of control, rejoice in it. The possibility of serving Christ, my GOD for the rest of my life... not only surrendering my life, but going a step further and actually laying my life at the feet of the most high God. The wise men brought spices and incense and gold to a baby... but as I approach the manger, I lay down in the straw my control, my future, my life as I know it now not belonging to me, but to Someone who can do far greater things with it than I can. I guess it's all about knowing who's in charge, and being ok with it. Reforming our idea of servantude and instead of struggling with it, be JOYOUS that we get this opporunity to discover, through being a servant to Christ, the meaning, the ESSENCE of what life is really all about; what it was created to be.

Ok, so I went to church this morning, and a million thoughts were racing through my mind all morning, and I am about to attempt to shorten them down to one post; forgive my failed effort if that is the result. I guess it started last night- I had a killer headache, and I SO did not want to wake up to go to church today (it's true, I guess it happens to the best of us : ). But I woke up this morning.... excited. SO excited to be going to participate in the act of worshipping God... not just the lifestyle, but the actual ACT of it. So I went to a church a lot like the church I grew up in, only like ten times better worship (both pastors blow me away though). So I got there, and this is where the conjungled thoughts begin (yes, I did make up that word). I was just... grateful for this crazy flawed institution we call the church. Can you imagine if we had to carry our faith by ourselves? It would be so screwed up! No WONDER God organized His body the way He did- we all compliment each other so well. Some have this gift, some have that gift, and it's when we stop looking at what a privelege it is to be a part of God's family- HIS ACTUAL BODY- that conflict arises over stupid things that don't even compare to what Christ did for us- what our focus SHOULD be on. It just struck me that as much as we complain about "the church," and as many things as we find to criticize about it, we are so fortunate for it, that we have each other as a source of encouragement, of love, of knowlege, of diversity IN Christ... and without that we'd be screwed. The church must be necesary if God created and organized it, and although today's church is probably not what God had in mind- Really, a unified body does NOT have like fifty thousand different denominations- it's still what God created and told us we need to be a part of it. So Thank God that He is so familiar with our weaknesses that He unified ALL of our weaknesses together for His glory.
The sermon today was amazing, and I got so much out of it and was so... just REFRESHED to be hearing and learning STRAIGHT from God's word... it was just like a sermon my old pastor (whom I miss) would've given... the sermon was on ministry, set in Hebrews ch. 13. But the point that really convicted me wasn't even from that passage- it was more from a subpoint that the pastor made from Romans, like one of the most popular verses in Romans (at least one of my favorites). Only even though I've read and studied this passage OVER AND OVER AGAIN, I never noticed this point taht leaped out of the passage this morning. ***Quick bunny trail*** The Jews say that the scriptures and the text is like a gem, and each time you turn it or study it it flickers in a new way, or produces a new color- each time the gem is turned, it reveals something new about itself, and this is the way that the Jews study the scriptures- something we could take a lesson from. So that's exactly what happened this morning in Romans Ch. 12 Verse 1. It got turned, and I saw a whole new color, and a whole new gleam that I'd never focused on before. So the verse says "Therefore, my brethren, I urge you by the mercies of God, that you present your bodies as a living sacrifice, holy and pleasing to God- this is your spiritual act of worship." Now I've always concentrated on the "Living Sacrifices" part of this, because what an amazing concept!! But take a gander (hehe, I said "gander") at that last part- THIS IS YOUR SPIRITUAL ACT OF WORSHIP. So when we go to church, and we carp and whine about how we want worship to be just like THIS, and we hope the message will be like THIS and not have all of THAT in it, and we hope so and so will be there, and then we COMPLAIN when it doesn't go that way... what an attitude to have towards our SPIRITUAL ACT OF WORSHIP. We should be excited to be able to worship God in whatever way we can! And if the worship isn't great, and if the sermon stretches our attention span, then SO BE IT. Because that's the kind of attitude we should have towards our spiritual act of worship- not one of "how can the church serve ME," but one of "my God, I am so fortunate to be able to participate in my act of worship this way this morning." We should be HUMBLE, without expectations when it comes to church. I am so guilty of this, you guys. SO guilty of this. And my whole aspect and outlook on what church is and how we should regard it was (THANK GOD) blown to pieces this morning.
And lastly the pastor told this story. He spoke of another pastor, who had a severely mentally handicapped daughter. His daughter would never speak other than in grunts and moans of pain and frustration; she would never walk, never marry, never smile, never carry on any resembleance of a lifestyle, PERIOD, let alone a typical one. And one day, while changing his SIXTEEN YEAR OLD DAUGHTER'S DIAPERS, staring at the essence of human grossness, while his full grown, woman of a daughter could only grunt in frustration at him, this pastor broke down in grief, frustration, and BITTER ANGER at God. And he yelled at God "WHY! Why is she like this?!? This, the epitome of human waste, without ability- my life is committed to this?!? To changing her diapers for the rest of my life?" And the man cried out in bitterness and anger at God. And God looked down at him and said "I change your diapers EVERY DAY. Every MOMENT I change your soiled diapers, full of lust, and greed, and sin, and other such dispicable actions, and I love you so much that I'm happy- HAPPY to do it."
This is such a humbling concept. My God, how much could you love me that You WILLINGLY change my soiled diapers everyday, leaving me clean of the filth of humanity.This is the tip of the iceburg, the merest understanding of Grace, and it's BEAUTIFUL.
Our God does this daily... cleanses us from such grossness that we bathe ourselves in...

So I was on my way home on Saturday night, and (I'm not gonna lie) I was pretty upset, so I stopped at my prayer garden to pray and get a handle on my emotions- after all, I was driving, and I made a promise to someone long ago that if I ever got too upset to drive, I would pull over. So I went to my garden. And I walked through the bushes, past the flowers, to the little stone bench which has been so faithful to me in the past- a familiar friend with which I've spent much time. I sat down, still crying, and I utterly cried out to God, as I tend to do often when I take things into my own hands, and one thought struck me- you know when a certain verse pops up at a certain time and you KNOW it's God, right? And the verse that FILLED my head and thoughts was Matthew 11:29-30- "Come to me, all who are heavy burdened, and I will give you rest. Take my yoke upon you, for my yoke is easy and my burden is light." This is Jesus talking. First of all, a little background here- what the heck is a "Yoke?" In Jesus' day, the most respected people of the time were Rabbi's. This is what every Jewish male aspired to be, but few made it. Now each Rabbi took a certain amount of students- appretices, if you will- and taught them teh scriptures. However, each Rabbi had a different INTERPRETATION of what a lot of the scriptures meant. So each Rabbi's set of interpretations was called that Rabbi's "yoke," and the goal of each student was to learn enough from the Rabbi to CARRY ON his yoke. And each of these yokes would be filled with rule after rule after rule, with different behaviors and traditions that one would have to follow... So when Jesus says, "take MY yoke upon you, for (it) is easy and my burden is light," He's saying "Hey! I don't require alot of rules or traditions. My yoke is easy to handle, easy to pass on, not tiresome (as the other Rabbi's yokes were) and it won't stress you out." (Wow, that was some paraphrasing, huh!?!?!) Meaning that His yoke is based in love, not in tradition or rules or condemnation- and love is a lot easier to bear than those other things. But the part of this verse that really struck me Saturday night was the "Come to me, all who are heavy burdened, and I will give you rest." We really don't have an excuse to be heavy burdened, do we? Because we know where rest is found- IT SAYS SO RIGHT HERE. So when we are weighed down, and we are emotionally exhausted, and we carry on this way for who knows how long- it's really kind of ridiculous. Because we don't HAVE To carry on that way, because it says right here where we can find rest. So right now, a VERY emotionally confusing time of my life where I try to decipher where God wants me and when, it doesn't have to be burdensome to be a test of my faith- because if I'm burdened, Jesus tells me right here where to go. If my focus is where it should be, I shouldn't be miserable,because Jesus promises me REST.

So this morning, one of my friends was leading worship at this Baptist church in Quincy, a small town just outside of Tallahassee. So we (two of my friends and I) decided to go and "support" him, because we haven't really settled on one church yet (I think the underlying issue is that I don't want to OFFICIALLY leave y'all!). So we went. Traditional... doesn't even begin to cover it. They sang 3 hymns, and that was the accumulation of worship this morning, which isn't persay BAD... but the Spirit of God wasn't in that place at all, and it seemed like that was ok with everyone- like there wasn't another alternative to that. The people were ABSOLUTELY sweet, and I've never been greeted by so many people on a Sunday morning IN MY LIFE (except in Poland), so that is most definitely in thier favor. They just... were complacent. It was the typical American church, and it was so sad! I wanted to jump up and scream "You can have to much more than this! This is not what freedom in Christ is! This is not what INTIMACY with Christ is!" But instead I sat, observed, and just...was a bit burdened (heavy-heart wise) for thier obvious bondage to church tradition. When the pastor prayed, it was as if he had rehearsed it before hand, because he prayed in like... almost old english. It sure wasn't modern speech. And it was filled with Christian Cliche's like "Washed in the blood of the lamb," and things like that. The sermon was had good points, but mainly it was general and broad... it was about sin, and his main point was what we could do to oversome sin, and what Jesus tells us to do. His big thing was how to be better "Christians," and on both of those points, all I could do was think about Ryan's message a few months ago, about how the biggest lie in church today is that WE can do it- but we can't, only Christ can. "Only one person ever truly lived the Christian life, so they named it after Him." (Ryan Jasper) I don't know if being a better "Christian" is even the point of why we're here. (I'm a little bit rambling here, but bear with me.) Is it possible to be a better "Christian?" Is that the point? Or are we just Christians period, and strive to be more like Christ? Because my thoughts tend to lie with the latter, that maybe the term "Christian" is so watered down today that the church no longer even knows what it means. To be a disciple... there's a lofty ambition worth striving after, which I guess is what the term "Christian" is supposed to be equivelant with. I'm sort of just writing as I think, in case you didn't get that. I'm trying very hard to seperate being judgemental of these people with what I'm actually feeling, and tha'ts compassion and a pity for them. The service seemed to be more out of tradition than that thier hearts were into it. I don't know what the point of al this ranting is... I guess be thankful. Be thankful that what y'all have at Faith Baptist and whatever anyone else has who's reading this...We have such a freedom in Christ, such a freedom to explore Him, to connect with Him, to see and feel and KNOW Him in our lives, and it's REAL, it's TANGIBLE, and it's not somehting we hear or read about...it's an experience we HAVE every DAY. Because that's not what it seemed like these people have, and they just represent the majority of American churches.What Christ offers us is much more than a Sunday morning service... He offers us a lifetime of more than we could ever imagine.

Don't be freaked out by this one- I've written tons of poems about the depression I went to, but never about the triumph over the depression (thanks to God). So... I know it's intense, but so was that period of my life. So this is the story of God's victory over my past.


Monsters
I used to have demons in my eyes,
threatening my sanity,
disrupting my clarity,
Stealing my peace-
Thieves.

I could feel them,
my eyes,
fill up with Fear,
Anger,
Anguish...

The green took on a 
haunted hue,
the verge of madness
expressed about the pupils,
creeping into my state of mind,
infiltrating the core of me.

My Greatest Nightmare
during the day;
the Voices beat pans
and wailed proud thier warrior cry.

My hands,
of thier own volition (It would seem)
flew to my ears;
not to block out the sound,
which was from within,
but in an act of pure
desperation,
determined not to let normalcy slip.

My clenched fist would
beat and clutch at my heart,
warding such demons from
my vulnerability,
A fultile effort;
For they didn't have to be in it
to destroy it.

Eventually,
as always,
such voices triumphed,
thier manipulative battle strategies
too strategic for
my distress,
and I would be left broken,
stripped,
naked,
unprotected,
and weak.

Where to turn 
when one hates oneself?
Where to go 
when the dependence upon sanity
withers as a flower,
A VIBRANT flower
on a hot day?
Reduced to a molten pile
of brown leaves,
and shrivelled petals,
hopelessness set in.

PICK YOURSELF UP,
OUT OF THE FETAL POSITION!
BRUSH BACK STRAY HAIRS,
MOP UP YOUR FACE FROM
YOUR PITIFUL ATTACK!
They scream.

And then they temporarily fade,
to just constant whispers
in my ear,
rather than clanging symbols
in my mind...
Hide, do they,
so I question whether they were
there at all.
Until next time
my eyes are clear,
if slightly guarded,
until they fill up with the color
of madness.

Such demons were driven,
as cattle,
from the core of me-
from thier base there.

The hue of my eyes remains green,
streaks of yellow my only scar
from a battlefield
within.
Exhaustion,
from a lifetime of war,
couples with disbelief
that the battle for
the territory OF ME
rests now,
resolved,
and I am weak.

Such Power in such light,
Such gratefulness in such humility,
my captors freed, replaced by
a new captor-
One who has captured my heart.
A baby,
A Carpenter,
A Rabbi,
A Warrior-
One who has fought courageously for
my freedom,
and one who has been victorious.

                                                 -Psalm 66:16

This verse is amazing. I'm going through the book of psalms, and I stumbled upon this verse this morning. We should be ready to do this at a moment's notice! BEG people to "hear," and be ready to "declare what He has done for (our) soul(s)!!!" Isn't this right here what evangelism is all about? Letting people know who God is, and what He's done in our lives? "Declare" has an authoritative ring to it, meaning that we should almost BOAST about what God's done for us; or we should say with complete certainty what God has done for us. Because we HAVE complete certainty. What He has done for my soul... where to even BEGIN??!!! This is our testimony in its purest form! Not some written out, cookie-cutter, step-by-step paragraph to be read from a paper... but what God has done for our SOULS. This begins with the gospel message, and moves onto what else He has been for you. For me, to name a few, He has been my Salvation, my stability, my comfort, my help, my safe place to go, my father, my friend, my joy, my peace, my redeemer (makes me new), my rock... and those are just a few! So what has God done for your soul, and are you out there declaring it?

It's funny, the way He works, isn't it? Not surprisingly, He's quite clever. No matter how far one runs, or drifts, or strays, He's still there. Regardless, one can still feel Him. Not with the same strength one once did, or perhaps stronger than one has before, but either way He's still there. It's almost like... there's this compartment BEHIND the heart, reinforcing it, compensating for its frailty. And it's His space, and His alone. It is the space that so many attempt to fill- and fail. He consumes it. Sometimes that fire burns, until it consumes your entire heart along with it. Sometimes it's not so consuming, and it flickers and smolders. But I do know that even when I"m doing nothing to stoke that fire, I can still feel it. It's a sense of peace, of purity, of understanding, of comfort, of a blanket of hope over pain. It's further proof of His amazing love. When I should be feeling grief, of pain, it's dimmed down to a dull ache, and invaded by gratitude, peace, and anticipation. And while that dull ache flares up, it dies back down, kept in its place by comfort. It doens't make much sense, but then, His workings seldom do. Though huge decisions await me, regardless of how monumentous they seem, I remain calm, and not of my own strength. So praise be to Him that we're so covered, so protected, so... cherished. Personally and individually cherished.

A Cast Away
A little girl
shy, timid,
captivating eyes-
so sad.
So young for such large tears.
A shaking hand 
holds out a 
flower for sale,
all she's got to offer
and for you to take.
A vibrant rose,
only source of color in her life.
Scraggly hair falls into her eyes
blinding her,
scaring her,
covering up her colorless face.
Her eyes plead with you to buy her treasure
her lifeline,
offered to you.
Wordlessly your cold eyes asses her.
You reach out,
and hope floods into her eyes,
temporarily replacing fear.
You take her rose,
twirl it,
play with her,
and drop the red symbol
to the gray ground.
Turn, walk away,
run and don't let

IF you look back,
you'll see her rejected form
bend,
retrieve her dirtied prize,
harbor it against her malnourished chest-
skin and bones.
IF you look back,
you'll see her raise
her empty eyes
to the gray sky,
and disappear into the rain.

A Poem that Does Not Mourn

Hope is alive,
refusing to be tampered 
despite my most valiant efforts.
My heart leaps,
skipping beats,
until it pauses in my throat
with fear or joy?
Or perhaps they are the same.
Lifelong hesitation is killed by
a few moonlit nights and
stolen glances
as I allow my once clear vision to
fade into starry eyes and
secret thoughts.
Never have I been so thoroughly feminine.
My arms ache with emptiness amidst
countless faces,
but the kind that will soon fade
as it is filled.
The exhilarating risk of the unknown elicits
pure fear,
but triumphs over 
lying in the comforting,
familiar
puddle of my own tears.
Smiles as secret as the Mona Lisa's
grace my lips
as my eyes glass over,
lost in the thought of you.
My face boasts the same king of
serene happiness
as a young woman who just found out-
but don't tell yet.
Her secret to keep,
soon her secret to share.
A kind of secret that
transforms a farm girl into a queen,
a kind of secret that
beckons even the hardest man to care;
a kind of secret that
takes a plain girl such as I
and whispers into her the breath that is
irresistibly woman.
So glorious,
this thing called love.

Hey you guys- could y'all please pray for me? I can't seem to shake this current funk I've been in since Peru. It feels like everything's pointless and I know it isn't... in my head. I just can't convince my heart of that. I miss everyone and everything like crazy. I went to Peru and lost a piece of my heart there, and it's taking me a while to adjust to living without that piece.

Peru was amazing. God changed my life, which I begged Him the entire time to do. I realized that I have a purpose in life, and it's not to putz around until He takes me. I knew that before, but now it's a reality. We truly had an amazing trip. I can't fit 18 days worth of doing God's work into this lj, but I can highlight a few events;

Our team did some puppet and clown ministries while we were in Peru. The funny thing about it is that we weren't prepared for these minitries AT ALL. For real. A week before the trip, we weren't even sure if we were going ot do them at all. We did two children's festivals; one at the church in Lima, and another in this lady's house in a section of Lima called San Juan. The first went well but the second... isn't it amazing how God can use even the minimalest efforts to bring HIm glory? Because through our unpracticed puppets and our highly unprofessional clowning, God brought 13 people to Himself for the first time. 13!!!!! 10 kids, 3 adults.

Later that night, we did a concert as an outreach. Keep in mind that all of us were getting sick, and I was pretty dang worried about it, 'cuase I had to sing. So as the days drew closer to the night of the concert, my vioce grew hoarser, the more worried I got, and the more God insisted I trust Him. So I did. At Saturday afternoon's practice, I could barely hit alto notes because my voice was so hoarse. And still God said "trust Me." So I got up on stage Saturday night and just worshipped Him, 'cause I realized that's what it's all about, and I could hit SOPRANO notes. God gave me my own little miracle.. Trust ME, God is trustable...

That night was the best night there for me. One of our most unexpected and yet most rewarding ministries there was working with the street kids. These kids had nothing.. they would come down from the hills (the poor area of town; there were barely houses up there, just slabs of plywood and cardboard) and do whatever they possibly could to earn money during the day; beg, sell small pieces of candy, do odd jobs, and then at night they'd go back to the hills. Let me tell you, we fell in love with these kids. At least, I know I did. Their cheerful faces, despite the dirt, the smell, the same threadborn clothes everyday in cold weather... and yet they were happy. And gosh I loved them. It got to the point to where our group couldn't even step outside the church without being surrounded by a group of them. At the concert on Saturday night, the youth pastor who took us gave the message, and my friend Andrew translated for him. I was sitting in between two streete kids. The one to my right was dead asleep, but Terri, the one on my left, was paying rapt attention. When Rob (pastor) prayed, and Andrew tranlated the prayer, Terri beside me repeated the prayer. So I asked him in spanish if he needed to talk to someone about what he just prayed, and he said he'd like to (he couldn't 've been more than 7 or 8). So he sat down with Rodrigo and Joel, two of the boys in the Peruvian youth group, and they talked to him and prayed with him and our first little boy accepted Christ as his savior. Then a girl named Corina sat down with two other little boys, Fedrik, who was one that we knew that best, and Diego, Terri's brother, and they both prayed and accepted God as well. Then Corina sat down with one other little boy, Jose, and Jose accepted God, too. So four of our kids accepted Jesus in one night. I can't remember a time when I was so happy. I was BAWLING. I had to literally leave the room 'cause the boys thought I was mad at them! It was so incredible...17 in one day!

So much more happened in Peru than this, and maybe I'll write more later. Please be praying for our kids, the four who accepted Christ and the million other street kids in Lima who are still out there, lost. Pray that these boys will continue growing in their faith, and that they'll bring their friends to the same hope they have, 'cause that's the only thing they've got. You know what kills me? That it was so easy. That it only took less than 2 weeks of doing nothing more than loving them for them to see Christ's love. Why aren't we like that? Oh to have the faith of a child...

I miss my kids.
